title: Ballistic pendulum lab to determine g

Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students are to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab by plotting data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes a dart of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and a block of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> hanging from the ceiling by light strings with negligible mass. The dart is launched with a speed of <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> towards the block. Assume that the velocity of the dart is horizontal when it collides with the block.

(a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols you defined in part (a) above.

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Another group of students performs the same experiment, but instead of light strings they use thin rods that have nonnegligible mass. If the students follow the same procedure and analysis as described in part (b) through part (d) without taking the mass of the rods into account, will the magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> calculated in this experiment be greater than, less than, or equal to the magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> calculated in the initial experiment?
